question: Question_02
statement:
For what values of p does $\int_e^\infty \frac{dx}{x(\ln{x})^p}$
converge?
sols:
First, write this integral as

$\int_e^\infty \frac{dx}{x(\ln{x})^p} = \lim_{b \to \infty} \int_e^b \frac{dx}{x(\ln{x})^p}$

Let $u = \ln(x)$. Then $du = dx/x$, $u(e) = \ln(e) = 1$ and
$u(b) = \ln(b)$. Then

\begin{align*}
\int_e^\infty \frac{dx}{x(\ln{x})^p} &= \lim_{b \to \infty} \int_e^b \frac{dx}{x(\ln{x})^p}\\
&= \lim_{b \to \infty} \int_1^{\ln(b)} \frac{du}{u^p}\end{align*}

At this point, we see that we need to break this up into two cases. The
integral above is different when $p = 1$ and when $p \neq 1$. So suppose
$p \neq 1$. Then we have

\begin{align*}
\int_e^\infty \frac{dx}{x(\ln{x})^p} &= \lim_{b \to \infty} \left. \frac{u^{-p+1}}{1-p}\right|_1^{\ln(b)} \\
&= \lim_{b \to \infty} \frac{\ln(b)^{-p+1}}{1-p} - \frac{1}{1-p}\end{align*}

This first term will tend to $0$ provided that $1-p < 0$ so whenever
$p > 1$. This term will tend to infinity when $p < 1$ since the
logarithmic term stays in the numerator. To take care of the $p=1$ case
that we have left out, we have

\begin{align*}
\int_e^\infty \frac{dx}{x(\ln{x})^1} &= \lim_{b \to \infty} \int_e^b \frac{dx}{x\ln{x}}\\
&= \lim_{b \to \infty} \int_1^{\ln(b)} \frac{du}{u}\\
&= \lim_{b \to \infty} \left. \ln(u) \right|_1^{\ln(b)} \\
&= \lim_{b \to \infty} \ln\ln(b) - \ln(1)\end{align*}

and this diverges. So our integral converges when $p > 1$ and diverges
when $p \leq 1$ as required.
hints: Try a substitution and then evaluating the integral directly.

Try the substitution $u = \ln(x)$ (Don't forget to substitute the
endpoints!)
You might want to isolate the case when $p = 1$
